prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not picking up my dogs poop
Now don't jump to conclusions 99% of the time my dogs poo is in the bin, but every 1 in a hundred poops from my dog is so vile it makes me throw up when I pick it up. I've done it before i.e thrown up while picking up one of these poops. I feel like leaving vomit in the park is worse than dog poop. Some people got mad at me the other day so I wonder AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The person is asking if they're in the wrong for not picking up their dog's poop when it's so vile it makes them vomit. They say 99% of the time they do clean it up, but in rare cases, the poop is so bad it causes them to throw up while picking it up. They argue that leaving vomit in the park is worse than leaving dog poop.

Hmm, first, general responsibility: as a dog owner, you're usually expected to clean up after your pet. That's a public hygiene thing, right? So even if it's once in a hundred times, not cleaning up at all might be seen as neglect. But the person is saying they're physically unable to do so because they get sick. That's a health issue. So if they can't control their reaction, maybe that's a valid reason. But maybe they should have someone else do it or use gloves and a tool to pick it up. Also, if they vomit while trying to clean up, maybe that's unhygienic. But the alternative is leaving the poop. 

Wait, the question is whether they're in the wrong. If they're in a public park, others might be upset if they don't clean up. Some people might be less understanding. Maybe they should take the dog elsewhere to do their business if they can't handle it. Or maybe they should have a plan for these rare cases. But the person's argument is that vomiting is worse. But maybe they should still clean up the poop and manage their own reaction. Also, if they've done it before, maybe they should have a method now, like using a shovel or gloves to avoid touching it directly. 

So, is it their fault? If they can't clean up in those rare cases, maybe they are in the wrong because they're not fulfilling their responsibility. But if they have a legitimate health issue (like their body reacting so badly they throw up), maybe they're not at fault. But maybe they should take precautions to avoid that. The answer depends on whether not cleaning up is their responsibility. Since they are supposed to clean up, even if it's difficult, maybe they're in the wrong. Alternatively, if the situation is so extreme that they can't help it, maybe not. But the fact that they threw up while picking it up is a problem. Maybe they should have a way to handle it without getting sick. 

I think the answer is A (they are in the wrong) because even if it's rare, they should clean up the poop. Leaving it is against public expectations and laws in many places. The vomiting is their own reaction, but they need to manage that. Maybe they should take a break and get help or use tools. So yes, they are in the wrong.
